## The http module allows our node application to listen for HTTP requests and send responses accordingly.

Fundamentally, that is what all a web server does.

Though we'll very soon be using Express to manage our web server, we can create a server in "plain" Node.js by loading the http core module and then passing a callback function to its `http.createServer()` method.

The callback function receives the request and response object then prepared and sends the appropriate response.

Once we defined our server, we then call its `listen()` method passing in the hostname and port to listen on.

### **Minimalist HTTP Server**

```javascript
"use strict";

// load the http module
const http = require("http");

// variables that the server will need
const hostname = "127.0.0.1";
const port = 3000;

// create our server by passing a callback to createServer
const server = http.createServer((req, res) => {
  // prepare and send an OK response
  res.statusCode = 200;
  res.setHeader("Content-Type", "text/plain");
  res.end("Hello Node Server");
});

// register the server to listen for requests
server.listen(port, hostname, () => {
  console.log(`Server running at http://${hostname}:${port}/`);
});
```

To test out our new-fangled server:

- Start the app if it is not already running
  - `npm run dev`
- Open a browser and navigate to [http://127.0.0.1:3000/](http://127.0.0.1:3000/)

![node server in browser](data:image/png;base64,)
